headline: Hot German Potato Salad
description: This hot German potato salad recipe is packed with flavor thanks to the addition of crispy bacon, tender onions, sugar, vinegar, and black pepper.

video.description: Want to try a different side with your sandwich?
video.name: Hot German Potato Salad III

name: Hot German Potato Salad

recipeInstructions.text: Place potatoes in a large pot and cover with salted water; bring to a boil. Reduce heat to medium-low and simmer until tender, about 20 minutes. Drain, cool, and slice thin.
Place bacon in a large, deep skillet. Cook over medium-high heat until evenly brown. Drain, crumble, and set aside, reserving drippings.
Sauté onions in bacon drippings over medium heat until they are golden brown.

Whisk flour, sugar, salt, celery seed, and pepper together in a small bowl; stir into onions and cook until bubbling, then remove from heat. Stir in water and vinegar; bring to a boil over medium heat, stirring constantly, and simmer for one minute. Gently stir bacon and sliced potatoes into the onion mixture until potatoes are heated through.

review.reviewBody: It needed a significant bit more sauce for the 9 potatoes. The second time I made it, I did half again all the sauce ingredients except vinegar and onion. I added about a half cup of diced peppers (banana & jalapeno) When browning the onions. mild-medium heat
To make it moister, I used 6 small red potatoes, unpeeled. To cut down on fat, I used pre-cooked bacon and used 1 T. butter to saute the onion. Loved how it turned out. Will save this recipe.

I loved this...made it a coupe times now...i use the whole pound of bacon...increase water to about a cup and a half and double the dry ingredients..i did NOT change the amount of vinegar (or potatoes) and found this more satisfactory for our taste.

Not bad... it was missing something but is overall a good base recipe. I did love the amount of bacon used; most recipes for German potato salad call for only 2-4 pieces of bacon (and we LOVE our bacon here). Maybe next time I'll add more celery seed.
This is just such a well seasoned and satisfying side for any pallet
Just like my mom made.

This is very good but I doctor it a little. I add a shot of Dijon mustard and chopped garlic. I uniformly cut up the potatoes before boiling. doesn't take as long to cook and not handling hot potatoes.
So good!

This is a very flavorful, traditional German potato salad. Didn't change a thing. I boiled potatoes a little too long, so texture was a little softer than ideal, but flavor was still fantastic. Will definitely make again.
I used 6 large baking potatoes. Tasty.
Tasted just like my grandmother's recipe, we ate growing up. I did double the sauce and added 1/4 cup more vinegar. Will be making again.
This was awesome, I did 1/4 cup white and 1/4 cup apple cider vinegar for a different tang.

Good German Salad. I had to adjust, because we did not have bacon (but I did have a jar of bacon grease in the fridge) to crumble into it.
Also added hard boiled egg like my German Nana use to do. 
If I had bacon, think I would give it 5 stars.
None
It was ok…

Delicious! On the advise of another reviewer I made the sauce at 1 1/2 times what was recommended except I didn’t increase the salt. I also increased the bacon to 9 slices (1 1/2 time). Thank you for the delicious recipe!
Delicious!!!

I have been looking for a Hot German Potato Salad recipe like the one my German Grandmother made years ago & this is close enough that I'm keeping it without changing much. I would maybe up the liquid by 30%. My German wife also loved it.
It turned out nicely. I guessed at quantity for 3 potatoes and my husband approved.
Really great.
Excellent!

Flavorful - absolutely! Oktoberfest authentic - not that I have ever had at Oktoberfest and I have been there multiple times, once for 6 straight days. There are so very many different recipes for all foods and never more true than here or in Germany. As indicated, the recipe has good flavor, and I like it, but this would most likely be served in a restaurant the plays with flavors. Potato salad in Southern Germany (Bavaria especially) is almost always potatoes, finely chopped onions, white vinegar, vegetable oil, salt, pepper, with a bit of water at times (the water the potatoes were boiled in). Some restaurants serve it warm, but mostly it's at room temperature or slightly chilled. Virtually any mayo-free German Kartofelsalad is fine with me, but it is usually a very simple side dish as above. Bacon is often added in northern Germany and sometimes in Schwabia.

German potato salad, has been a long time favorite of mine, enjoyed it from the time of childhood, the recipe here is the same as my Mother's. I just made it again, absolutely sooooo delicious. It's so good warm when just made, actually seems to get better with a day or so in the fridge. I used very lean bacon, and a bit more than the recipe calls for.

I hadn't had German potato for years and this one was pretry close to the one I used to make.
It needed more seasoning which I kicked up a bit. Was really good.
I’ve made this recipe numerous times. Since I’ve been letting the potatoes cool off and cut them in larger chunks they don’t fall apart. My husband loves it too.

This is good, but I did make a few changes related to our tastes. My kid won't eat onion, so I snuck in some onion powder. I also doubled the vinegar, so mine is a little soupier, but I'm OK with that. I also despise celery, so no surprise that I don't have any celery seed on hand, so I subed in some dill. I think it's still really good. I'd make it again.
Apple cider vinegar (doubled), chicken broth instead of water, and added celery. Sliced potatoes before boiling, of course. 10 star

I had lost my old recipe that called for celery seed, so I was delighted to find this one. This salad turned out just like the one I used to make in Karlsruhe. I am happy with the quantity of vinegar, and I think this salad is delicious.
I've made this 5 or 6 times now and just love it. I season a little more strongly than recipe.
The best German potato salad I have tried . Every one loved it. !!!!!
Thank you for a wonderful recipe. I wii be making this again. I did cut the salt in half because I increased the bacon by 50%

I have made and served this several times and it is always a hit. I usually use a bit more onion (because I love them) and a bit more vinegar (because I love the sauce!) This is a great side fresh and hot, cooled and as a left-over, even reheated in a skillet as a breakfast hash. Great tasting versatile recipe.
Made per recipe except used 6 potatoes instead of 9 so that there was a higher ratio of the bacon/onion mixture. Would do same next time as it wouldn't have been enough for 9 potatoes.
Excellent, I used cider vinegar and brown potatoes because that’s what I had in hand. This is a keeper!
I liked this recipe very much. I will be using it again. Thanks
I made it as it was written. Took it to a German themed party and everyone said it was good.
my hubby made this and followed as written. came out great. used for home fries with breakfast the next day.

First let me say I'm 64 years old and I've always detested German potato salad. While my poor husband loves it, I've never made it. For a recent outdoor get together I decided to make this. Let me say everyone loved it, including myself. While I followed the ingredients to a T I did alter the amounts. I used about 3 pounds unpeeled (I'm lazy) red potatoes, about 3/4+ pounds thick cut bacon and 1.25 cups onion and doubled the sauce. While I doubled the sauce I did not double all the amounts. For double the sauce I used: 2 tsp of flour, 2 tsp of sugar, 2 tsp of salt (might go 2.5 or 3 next time), 1 tsp celery seed (might try 1.5 next time), 1/4 tsp pepper, 1.5 cups water and 2/3 chips white vinegar. When it was done I put it in an uncovered crockpot just to keep it warm. I was not impressed when it was first finished but after sitting for an hour or two in the crockpot it was delicious. So my take-a-way: This must sit for a period of time so that the flavors will meld. This was really good and quite the hit. I will make this many more times. Thank you for this recipe.
I will make again. Added a little more liquid to thin out and a little salt at the end.
Pretty good. I'm looking for a german potato receipe like Schmidt's in Columbus OH - this was close. Not enough of a vinegar taste for us, maybe we'll adjust next time. Good though!
I used russet potatoes because was the one available at home, I was out of celery seed so I follow the conversion with celery (google) ... everything came out AWESOME.
I liked this recipe very much, loved the tanginess and the bacon. Good flavour.

I added like 1 more TB of flour, and a few more strips of bacon and almost a cup of vinegar. (Have to taste the vinegar to me)
But everyone loved it.
 Will be definitely be making this recipe again.
Thank you
I loved it. I added kielbasa to the onion and bacon drippings then followed the recipe.
Delicious! Made it with fewer potatoes because that was all I had. Didn't change anything else. So good!

Fabulous! I use Red potatoes if I have them but I've made it with Russet as well. ***TIP ***make sure you stop boiling the potatoes when they are still firm or they will fall apart when slicing and stirring. Also I put mine in a colander and run cold water over them or they will continue to cook if left in the hot water. Really good as is but easy to tweak if you like extra sauce or more vinegar...

Fabulous! I use Red potatoes if I have them but I've made it with Russet as well. ***TIP ***make sure you stop boiling the potatoes when they are still firm or they will fall apart when slicing and stirring. Also I put mine in a colander and run cold water over them or they will continue to cook if left in the hot water. Really good as is but easy to tweak if you like extra sauce or more vinegar...
Loved it. I only had precooked bacon which didn’t produce enough grease. Used about 10 slices. Had to add 2T butter to get the roux set. It turned out great.
Good but not what I remember from my Aunt Elfriede. Was a little bland and dry. Maybe soaking longer as others have suggested would help.

WAY too much flour. Next time I make this I am going to try a bit less than 1 tablespoon or maybe none at all-----defintely not two tablespoons. The "extra" flour made the salad a bit gluggy and slightly dissatisfying.

Also: I wish the person sharing this recipe would specify in the ingredients list the weight of the potatoes or at least the size of the "9 potatoes." I am certain I'm not the only cook wondering just what size/type/amount of potatoes to use.

And: I agree with earlier commenter who said a bit more vinegar would be better. I took her advice and added another two tablespoons (white wine vinegar) to my recipe.

Other than the flour mishap and having to guess at true amount of potatoes-----this recipe is a keeper.

Oh-----and I used veggie bacon. Delicious.

I would suggest a slight variation to the Recipe. Use boiled red potatoes that are allowed to cool down after cooking and then skinned. Allow the bacon fat to cool down and then add a small portion for the dressing mixture of mayo, vinegar, sugar and small dab of sweet spicy German mustard. Do not heat this dressing. I would also recommend adding chopped boiled eggs, chopped pickles and chopped celery to the potato salad.
I didn't make any adjustments ... delicious just as it was written. I prepared it ahead of time, placed it in a casserole dish and heated it in a 350 degree oven for 30 mins.
Wonderful, didn’t change anything and is turned. out great. It is a keeper.
Very good! I didn't have bacon so diced some smoked sausage. Also didn't have celery seed so used celery salt. We really enjoyed it.

I cut the potatoes into four pieces so only took about 15 minutes to cook. I found the sauce to be in perfect ratio to the potatoes. I made as directed and put into a slow cooker set to warm for an hour before serving so I could fully concentrate on the chicken dish I was also preparing. Delish.
This is a favourite. A regular side dish when we eat pork & my favourite potluck dish to make. It's always eaten up with nothing left to clean up & easy to make with inexpensive, on hand ingredients.
Do you keep it warm in crockpot?
super easy and the family loved it!
Great!

We loved this salad! I did double the bacon, as we are bacon lovers. I used red new potatoes, 4-1/2 pounds. Even with the red potatoes, felt it lacked in the eye appeal so added scallions and parsley, too. Took it to a party last night, and there was zero left, so I am now making it again today! That's how good it is! Thanks for a great recipe!
Easy to make and tastes delicious!
Excellent. Just excellent. Made exactly as written
Too vinegary

This is very close to the German potato salad I used to make, then lost the recipe. The changes I made were to add about 1 tsp of ground mustard, and since I love the dressing so much, I double upon the ingredients and triple to quadruple the bacon (because the only thing better than bacon is more bacon). It freezes well, but the potatoes get a bit mushy when reheated, so the texture is almost like a very chunky mashed potato salad.
Made it per the recipe. Thought is was very close to my grandmothers. I was short 2 potatoes, but still was delicious.
Excellent! I cut down on the vinegar by half for the someone who doesn’t like vinegar flavour. We both enjoyed this dish!

Excellent! Very c;lose to my mother's recipe (never written down) so, I combined the two for the sake of measurements.
I replaced the celery seed with fresh chopped parsley.
I have made this recipe twice. Husband likes this. This recipe has more mild flavor that my guy prefers. I have made this a few times for him, adding more onions.

This is fantastic! It never lasts more than a day in my house, the family can’t get enough of this delicious potato salad. I do add more bacon and onion and use apple cider vinegar for some extra tang.

Made this dish for my sons high school basketball banquet, was so well received that by the time I went through the line it was already gone. Used redskin potatoes 5 lb. bag, sliced potatoes thick and boiled till partially cooked. Doubled the sauce ingredients, substituting apple cider vinegar, and brown sugar. Cooked in oven covered, one hour at 350.

I use apple cider vinegar and a T dijon in my dressing. If you can get them, it is great to use kipferl potatoes, also known by most as banana potatoes. They are small and waxy, hold their shape and easy to peel after cooking. My MIL was Austrian and this was what she taught me. RIP Rosie bussi.
Our family loves it so much that the recipe makes it into our monthly rotation!
Great taste! I subbed the apple cider vinegar for white vinegar, and only used 1/2 teaspoon celery seed. My husband and company loved it!

My daughter had to take a cultural dish to school to share with her class. We chose this recipe and it turned out great! Thanks for the recipe! Fun to connect to our German heritage. We used russet potatoes and 1/8 t. celery salt because I didn't have celery seed. I diced the potatoes before boiling and boiled for only 10 minutes which was more than enough time. Yummy!

This was fine. If I were making it for dinner, perhaps it would've been great, but for a party, it wasn't the best choice. I spent far too much time during the party trying to coordinate this so it would still be hot. Ended up with good flavor, but kind of gluey (I used red potatoes). Won't likely make it again because we don't eat a lot of potato salad, but for another person, this might be great.
I made it last night. I substituted a pound of Italian sausage for the bacon, milk for the water and didn't use flour. Yum!!! Everyone loved it!
perfect balance between the vinegar and sweetness of the sugar. My husband is a german potato salad snob and he LOVED it!!

The bacon I used was already pretty salty so I would recommend not adding any additional salt to the dry mix. I also wasn't crazy about the celery seed. It is a strong bite when you eat one, but overall it was really good.
I've tried many recipes for German Potato Salad, but this is the best. Very flavorful
Great recipe, only difference was we didn't have any hot German around so I had to use ugly American but it was delicious all the same, bone app the teeth!
Husband and I love it will make again!
This is a really nice change from the traditional mayo based potato salad. I didn't need to change a thing.

Yum! I pressure cooked unpeeled potatoes then let them cool slightly before slicing. I added some fresh parsley for color. The only change I would make is less vinegar and/or more sugar. It was perfect for me but a little vinegary for most!
very good, i would recommend using more bacon and adding accent or salt to taste at the end. I also garnished with chives and it turned out great

This potato salad is wonderful, I got the recipe in 2006 and made it again this morning , the flavor is so good made exactly
as written. I ate just the salad for brunch today.
My son and husband really enjoyed this recipe. I used six med. large red potatoes, 1/4 cup of cider vinegar because a similar recipe using 1/3 was too sharp. Will definitely use this recipe again.
Good recipe. I added kielbasa to make it a full meal.
Whole family loved it!
Loved it! My fiancé was over in Germany a lot and said this recipe tasted really good!
Delicious! I made no changes, and I'll most definitely be making it again.

Took this to Christmas dinner and everyone had 2nds. 
I reserved the potato water, used some to cook a pkg. of cut green beans which I also stirred into the potatoes. If you like sweet and sour green beans this will work for you. The rest of the potato water will go with the rest of the leftovers for soup tonight.

I have made this recipe numerous times. My only change is, I cut up the red potatoes before boiling them. It is the best potato dish my family has ever had. My hubby and son ask for it daily, lol. But we don't really have it that often, just a few times a month and on holidays!

Delicious, old fashioned German Potato Salad. I bake batches of bacon, then freeze the cooked strips. No bacon grease was available, so I just used 1/2 T butter to brown the onions. I ended up browning the flour mixture in the cooked onions, then added the vinegar and water to make a gravy. After draining the potatoes, let them sit over low heat for a bit to release the steam before adding the sauce. The potatoes will stay formed and not be as gummy.

This recipe sounds great but whoever reads this review PLEASE LISTEN. This is a family secret from my German ancestors... do not drain the bacon fat,save it in the pan low heat and simmer, then add your spices and onions as well as your vinegar, simmer 3-5 minutes making sure not to burn, then pour over potatoes. This makes the dish much more flavorful and savory. Truly the ultimate comfort food.
Made this for an Oktoberfest party and it was a hit! I used red potatoes and made 1-1/2 times the amount of sauce (since people were saying it tended to be dry), and it was perfect.

Tastes exactly like my favorite German restaurant. Family loved it. Used red potatoes , didn't overcook them so mine looked better than the photo. Will definitely make again. Served with red cabbage and pork.
This was really good. I have never ate hot potato salad, it went over really good here. I did had more bacon though. I will make this again!!!
This was really good. Just a little to sweet. I will make it again with half the sugar.

I had never made German Potato Salad before so wasn't sure what to expect. Turned out great. A nice side dish with a different taste that I will make a little more often. Goes great with chops or brats. I liked the suggestion of using an egg slicer to cut the potatoes.
